description: From Middle French ethnarque, and its sources, New Latin ethnarcha, Koine Greek ἐθνάρχης (ethnárkhēs, “ruler of a tribe or nation, title of a Jewish official”), from Ancient Greek ἔθνος (éthnos, “nation”).

entries.meaning: (historical) The governor of a Jewish province under the Roman Empire.
examples: In the course of the struggle with the unfortunate ethnarch, the nobles had found it expedient to attach themselves to Rome.

entries.meaning: A leader of an ethnic community, especially a Jewish or (in the Ottoman Empire) Eastern Orthodox leader having political as well as spiritual authority.
examples: The Archbishop became the ethnarch, the leader of the ethnic group. It was  his responsibility to administer the territories where his people lived, to collect taxes and to regulate matters relating to marriage, divorce, dowry and inheritance.
